tweet: If you or a veteran you know is in crisis, call the Veterans Crisis Line at 1-800-273-TALK (8255) and press 1, or text 838-255.

A nationwide stand-down would:
1. Ensure all VA staff are fully trained
2. Assess facility infrastructure
3. Identify gaps in policies, procedures & resources

Each day 20 veterans, servicemembers, reservists & members of the National Guard die by suicide—it’s clear we’re not doing enough to support veterans in crisis. Proud to join Chairman Takano in calling for a VA stand-down & thankful for his leadership on this life-saving issue. https://twitter.com/RepMarkTakano/status/1166410989782351872 …

This has been a team effort, and I’m honored to have worked jointly with @RepJudyChu & the VA to make this day a reality. We thank all of our veterans—men & women—and their families, and we will never forget their service and sacrifices to our nation! pic.twitter.com/YoB1vRizyD

Been a long time coming, but today we celebrated the opening of the new VA San Gabriel Valley Community Outpatient Clinic! Located in Arcadia, this facility will better serve the medical needs of veterans in the Greater SGV & reduce the time required to access & receive care. pic.twitter.com/0A7NGmiBHK

ALL citizens deserve an equal opportunity to vote, regardless of race, ethnicity, religion, language abilities, or other things that set us apart. We must restore the vote! #VRA54 #GiveUsTheBallot #RestoreTheVote #ForThePeople

The Supreme Court’s Shelby v. Holder decision in 2013 invalidated key protections within the VRA, and since we have seen states enact bills to suppress the vote of communities of color. These regressive laws threaten our hard-fought progress. We must not go back!

54 years ago, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the #VotingRightsAct (VRA) to ensure everyone, especially minority citizens, could participate fully in our democracy without fear of threats or discrimination. #VRA54 pic.twitter.com/yY7XkmUQZW

Repeating the NRA’s myth that mental illness is to blame only further increases harmful stigma and ignores the central role guns play in mass shootings. No policy should stigmatize individuals w/ mental illness or discourage them from seeking treatment.

Gun violence is NOT caused by mental illness.

Mental illness only accounts for approx. 4% of violence in U.S.
